title: Implementation Checklist
content:
This section contains an example implementation checklist you can use to guide you through the minimal steps to prepare a system for use by end users and agents.

While not every area in the system is covered, the necessary steps are included for the initial setup and the most popular modules. Links to relevant documentation are also provided.

Setup Core Data & Customization

The core data (such as location and group definitions) is widely used in different modules. This makes it quite important to implement early in the implementation process while ensuring the data is correctly created (or imported). 

For high-level information on the types of core data needed, see the Getting Started guide here. For information about how to import data, see Import Data Format.

☐ Review out-of-the-box Roles and modify or add as necessary

Review the roles documentation, which includes a list of out of the box roles.

☐ Create or import Location data

For more details, please review the Locations section in the Getting Started guide.

☐ Create or import Organizational Groups

Organizational Groups contain all the boxes on the company’s org chart. Business units, departments, and the company itself are represented as separate but related Organization Groups. 

The Organizational Group also contains information about the Owner/Manager of the Group and all the members of the Organization. Note that a person can only belong to one Organizational Group.

☐ Create or import Functional Groups

Functional Groups contain the people responsible for a specific job function or process within the system.  These groups can encompass people who belong to several Organizational Groups or may be used to further break up Organizational Groups into different functions that they support.  For example, within a Department that builds a specific product we can create separate Functional Groups for the Database team, the UI team, and the Application team.  It's also important to note that people can belong to multiple Functional Groups, so people that support multiple processes can belong to all the teams that are necessary.  

The main thing you will use Functional Groups for is to assign “work”. When you want a specific “Team” to work on a Request, Incident, Change, or even a Task, assign a Functional Group to the record you want them to work on.  From there, you can also assign a specific Group member to the record, so it's not only important to define the Groups but to make sure the correct people are part of the Group.

☐ Import any Users that were not part of the SSO integration

You can perform simple imports through the UI, but for more complex information consider using the Manage Persons API.

☐ Create or import Contacts (non-users) into the system

☐ Assign Users to Roles, Locations, and Groups

For small implementations, this may be manually done, but most implementations will require the use of the Manage Persons API to make bulk updates.  

The Connect-It product is one tool that can move information from your internal data sources to Service Management.  Connect-It makes use of the Manage Persons API so you can add attributes, set licensing, and add Users to Roles and Groups.

☐ Customize the notification header & footer

For example, you can replace the logo with your organization's logo. 

☐ Update Agent training material with Location and Group information if needed

Define your primary services

Services are at the core of most processes within Service Management. Taking the time to define your services fully will improve the productivity of these processes, notably the Service Catalog. You can find more information on defining your services and examples in the SACM Overview chapter of the Getting Started guide.

 
☐ Create Service Definitions for a few of your most important/used Services

For information on adding the Service Definitions, see here.

☐ Create the Actual Service entries that represent these Services in your environment 

For details and an examples, see here.

 
☐ Where possible, define the Service Component/System Element hierarchy under these Services

For more details, see this chapter in the Getting Started guide.

 
☐ (optional) Set the primary Functional Groups responsible for supporting these Services either in the Actual Service or an associated Routing Definition

☐ Update Agent training material with Service information

Setting up Request Management

Request management handles the end to end process of receiving a request from an end user and fulfilling it. A request management process reduces the load on agents by allowing end users to fulfill their own requests without agent involvement either by automating common request offerings (such as password resets) or providing knowledge that will allow the end user to answer a question by themselves. For more information, please read the Request Management chapter in the Getting Started guide.

☐ Review the default Record Categories, adding or removing where necessary

For additional details, see this section in the Getting Started guide.

☐ Import existing Knowledge Articles

For information on packaging existing articles and importing them into Service Management,see here.

☐ Review Request Roles and ensure Agents have correct Roles

☐ Review default Views and Reports, editing or adding if necessary

For more information, see this section of the Getting Started guide.

☐ Implement a satisfaction survey if desired

For further explainations of surveys, see this section of the Getting Started guide.

☐ Define a default Service Level Agreement with Service Targets for Support Requests

For more information, see the Service Level Management section of the Getting Started guide .

☐ Update Agent training materials with Request Management process flows

The Service Catalog

To consume the services IT provides, the end users need to have a way of discovering the services available and what actions or requests they can perform against them. The service catalog provides the means of creating those available choices for both the Service Portal (accessed by the end users) and request management (accessed by the agents). 

Before creating your Service Catalog, we recommend reading the associated chapter in the Getting Started guide.

☐ Create the high-level Service Category structure with existing Service Definitions

For examples and further information on setting up the category structure, see the related information here in the Getting Started guide.

☐ Create any necessary Entitlement records to attach to Offerings

☐ Create a few Offerings for each Service

For information on setting up offerings, see here in the Getting Started guide.

☐ Customize the Self Service Portal look & feel

For example of a tailored service portal, see here.

☐ Update end user training materials with Self Service Portal information
 

Setting up Incident Management

An Incident encompasses any disruption or degradation of a service, whether the service is internal or external. Issues with redundant hardware (or software) are also handled as an incident, even if the degradation isn't apparent to an end user.

The goal of the incident management process is to resolve the disruption or degradation as quickly as possible. This may often involve enacting a workaround (such as rebooting a server or restarting a specific service) rather than a permanent fix.

We highly recommend reviewing the Incident Management chapter in the Getting Started guide before starting your implementation.

☐ Import existing Knowledge Articles

☐ Review Incident Roles and ensure Agents have correct Roles

☐ Review default Views and Reports, editing or adding if necessary

☐ Define a default Service Level Agreement with Service Targets

For more information, see the Service Level Management section of the Getting Started guide .

☐ Create Incident Models and or Templates to assist with Incident creation

For explanation and examples, see the Incident Models section of the Getting Started guide.

☐ Update Agent training materials with Incident Management process flows

Setting up problem management

A problem is simply the cause of one or more incidents. The aim of the problem process is to minimize the impact of known problems on consumers and prevent recurring incidents.

Problem management encompasses the activities required to diagnose the root cause of incidents and determine short term workarounds and long term resolutions to those problems. It's also responsible for ensuring the correct resolutions are implemented through the correct control processes such as change management and release management.

For more information, see Problem Management chapter of the Getting Started guide.

☐ Import existing Knowledge Articles

☐ Review Problem Roles and ensure Agents have correct Roles

☐ Review default Views and Reports, editing or adding if necessary

☐ (optional) Create Problem Templates to assist with Problem creation

☐ Update Agent training materials with Problem Management process flows

Setting up Change Management

Changes to IT infrastructure may be necessary to respond to problems or externally imposed requirements and to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of existing services. The change management process ensures that standardized methods, processes, and procedures are used for all changes to give efficient and safe handling of all changes to the infrastructure, and is used to determine that the need for change outweighs the potential detrimental impact of changes.

The Change Management chapter of the Getting Started guide contains additional information on setting up the module.
